title: Enhancing Cybersecurity Detection Quality: Advanced SOC Techniques and Best Practices
description: Learn how to master next-level detection quality in cybersecurity with advanced SOC analysis, threat validation methods, and real-world detection engineering techniques. Ideal for students aiming for elite SOC Level 3 skills.
author: Maurice Lambert

slides.title: The Rapid Evolution of Cybersecurity: Key Events, Challenges, and Lessons for Today
Major Milestones in Cybersecurity | 2010 - 2017

texts.content: Cybersecurity grew rapidly and often reactively. Key events during 2010-2017 shaped both perception and practice.

content: Stuxnet (2010): Cyber was mostly invisible to the public, used by governments as a precise, sophisticated tool; feared but understood by very few.
Snowden Leaks (2013): Cyber capabilities exist in governments, with global reach; impact is potentially huge, but execution remains in expert hands.
WannaCry Ransomware (2017): Cyber attacks hit enterprises worldwide; threat is now professional, financially motivated, and no longer limited to state actors.

texts.content: This period marks the shift from experimental cyberattacks to real-world business impact, showing why cybersecurity became urgent for organizations worldwide.

slides.title: Cybersecurity Costs vs. Benefits | Investment Dilemma

texts.content: Cybersecurity is a significant investment for organizations, often without direct financial return.

content: High Costs: Tools, platforms, SOC teams, training, insurance
Limited Direct ROI: Security spends rarely generate revenue
Marketing & Reputation: Cybersecurity often becomes a selling point ("we are secure")
Strategic Challenge: Balancing risk reduction with budget constraints

texts.content: Understanding costs and benefits helps organizations make informed security decisions and avoid superficial implementations.

slides.title: Legal & Regulatory Pressure | When Compliance Creates New Risks

texts.content: Regulations push companies to "do cybersecurity", but the way compliance is applied today often creates new risks, unnecessary complexity, and even technical weaknesses.

content: Misaligned Requirements: Generic controls imposed by compliance may not fit the company's real architecture, sometimes forcing weak or risky implementations.
New Vulnerabilities Introduced: To meet legal expectations, organizations sometimes deploy solutions without or even against the advice of technical teams, increasing the attack surface.
Complexity Explosion: More tools, more processes, more audits → infrastructures become heavier and harder to secure, especially for SOC teams.
Security Degradation: Compliance obligations can reduce real defensive quality, diverting experts from technical priorities to administrative tasks.
Cost Without Protection: Spending rises, but actual protection doesn't and may even deteriorate.

texts.content: Compliance helps companies acknowledge cybersecurity, but the current compliance-driven approach can increase risks. Defenders must manage these consequences every day.

slides.title: Consequences of Rapid Cyber Development | Partial & Imperfect Security

texts.content: Because cybersecurity grew too fast and under pressure, many organizations ended up with incomplete, inconsistent, or poorly integrated security measures.

content: Partial Implementations: Tools deployed without full configuration or not used to their full potential.
Strategic Gaps: Security choices made quickly, without long-term vision or alignment with real threats.
Fragmented Architectures: Layers of solutions added over time → inconsistent coverage and blind spots.
Operational Overload: SOC teams must defend environments that are complex, noisy, and full of gaps.
Quality Issues: Many controls exist "on paper" but provide little real protection in practice.

texts.content: The fast, unstructured development of cybersecurity created fragile foundations today's defenders must navigate these weaknesses while building something stronger for the future.

slides.title: The Path to Quality Cybersecurity | Learning From the Last 10 Years

texts.content: Cybersecurity has grown fast, sometimes too fast. But we are now entering a phase where quality, prioritization, and technical mastery become essential.

content: Only ~8 years of real investment: Modern cybersecurity budgets started around 2017 → systems are still young, fragmented, and evolving.
Shift in Mindset: Organizations begin to move from "adding more tools" to identifying what truly matters and improving it properly.
Effective Defense With Lower Operational Cost: The goal is not to remove tools, but to implement defenses correctly, which naturally reduces complexity, effort, and therefore costs.
Better Foundations: Architecture, detection, and processes are finally stabilizing and becoming more reliable and sustainable.
Your Opportunity: You will work in cybersecurity for the next 30-40 years. You'll help build the next generation of defenses, based on quality instead of urgency.
Course Objective: Go beyond today's SOC practices and give you the technical understanding and defensive mindset required for tomorrow's cyber challenges.

texts.content: The strength of tomorrow's cybersecurity will come from skilled people who know how to build and operate defenses effectively.

slides.title: Inside Real Incidents: How Companies Create Their Own Vulnerabilities
Compliance-Driven Design That Broke Security

content: Large enterprise preparing for ISO 27001 certification.
Decision: deploy a "security layer" to control server access management.
Technical reality: solution relied on virtual segmentation only (VLAN isolation for a few machine groups).
The new component could not support encryption in the environment's architecture.
As a result, all authentication flows, including domain and domain admin passwords, were transmitted in cleartext on the network.
For more than 3 years, this system ran in production without being integrated into security monitoring.
Created a massive blind spot: server access invisible to SOC tools.
Introduced a perfect vector for stealthy persistence if an attacker entered the network.
Increased operational burden: more patching, more maintenance, more procedures, more attack surface.
All of this added for compliance, yet it reduced real security.

texts.content: Even once governance was aware of the vulnerability, no one was tasked with fixing it. The main concern of the ISMS: updating TLS certificates from 1.2 to 1.3 for compliance, not mitigating the actual security risk.

slides.title: EDR Implementation Misaligned with Actual Needs

content: Year 2020: EDR solutions become standard and widely promoted in the industry.
The CISO decides to deploy one based solely on sales numbers and price, without consulting the technical teams.
By 2023, it became clear that the chosen EDR was not effective for the organization's environment.
The solution did not meet actual security needs, missing coverage compared to other available options.
The organization had poor visibility into the SI, and the EDR gave a false sense of security, with detections often misleading or incorrect.
2024: after a POC with a better EDR, the organization switches, recovering more than 6 months of work and training that could have been avoided.
Demonstrates the cost of decision-making without technical input: time, effort, and potential gaps in security during the interim.

texts.content: Decisions must include technical assessment and alignment with real security needs to avoid wasted effort, false confidence, and increased risk. Choosing tools based on market hype or price alone can be costly.

slides.title: Core Principles and Structure of a Security Operations Center
What Is a Security Operations Center (SOC)? | Cybersecurity Monitoring & Defense Overview

texts.content:
A Security Operations Center (SOC) is the centralized team responsible for monitoring, detecting, and responding to cybersecurity threats across an organization.
Mission:

content: Ensure continuous protection of IT assets
Identify malicious activity early
Coordinate incident response and improve security posture
Acts as the nerve center for cyber defense
Evolves from basic monitoring to intelligence-driven operations
Integrates people, processes, and technology to manage risk effectively

slides.title: SOC Organizational Models | Centralized, Distributed & Outsourced SOC

texts.content:
A SOC can be organized in several ways depending on the organization's size, resources, and security strategy.
Common SOC Models:

content: Centralized SOC: Single location monitoring all systems; strong control and coordination
Distributed SOC: Multiple locations, often across regions; better local coverage
Virtual SOC: Remote teams leveraging cloud tools; flexible and cost-efficient
Outsourced SOC (MSSP/MDR): Managed by third-party providers; complements internal capabilities
Trade-offs between cost, coverage, and control
Organizational fit depends on risk tolerance and regulatory requirements
Hybrid models often combine internal and external resources for optimal performance

slides.title: SOC Roles and Responsibilities | Key Cybersecurity Functions

texts.content: A SOC relies on specialized roles to detect, analyze, and respond to threats efficiently.

content: Tier 1 Analyst: Monitors alerts, triages incidents
Tier 2 Analyst: Investigates and escalates complex incidents
Tier 3 Analyst / Threat Hunter: Performs deep analysis, proactive threat hunting
Incident Responder / DFIR Specialist: Leads incident, containment, eradication, recovery
SOC Manager & Engineers: Coordinate operations, maintain tools and processes

texts.content: Clear role definition ensures fast, accurate response and reduces alert fatigue.

slides.title: SOC Processes & Workflows | Monitoring, Detection & Response

texts.content:
SOC processes structure how security events are handled from detection to resolution.
Core Workflow Steps:

content: Monitoring & Alerting: Continuous surveillance of networks, endpoints, and cloud
Triage & Investigation: Validate and analyze alerts
Containment & Eradication: Stop threats and remove them from the environment
Recovery & Lessons Learned: Restore systems and improve defenses

texts.content: Well-defined processes and playbooks ensure fast, consistent, and effective incident handling.

slides.title: Logging & Telemetry Fundamentals | Essential SOC Data Sources

texts.content:
Effective SOC operations depend on high-quality logs and telemetry from all parts of the IT environment.
Key Log Sources:

content: Network: Firewalls, IDS/IPS, routers
Endpoints: EDR/XDR agents, OS logs
Cloud & Applications: Cloud workloads, SaaS apps, APIs
Identity & Access: Authentication systems, IAM platforms
Ensure log quality, consistency, and retention
Normalize and enrich logs for better detection
Prioritize logs that support incident response and compliance

texts.content: Visibility is the foundation of SOC effectiveness. You can't secure what you can't see.

slides.title: Detection Engineering Essentials | SOC Threat Detection & Analytics

texts.content: Detection engineering is the art of turning logs and telemetry into actionable alerts for the SOC.

content: Choose the right tool: test all predefined alert tools (EDR, NDR, UEBA, ...)
Anomaly detection & analytics: Identify unusual behavior patterns
Rule-based detection: SIEM correlation rules for known threats
MITRE ATT&CK alignment: Map detections to attacker techniques
False positives management: rewrite the rule with a good detection strategy (do not adjust alerts to reduce noise -> risks of true negatives, exclusion management)

texts.content: Effective detection requires good quality rules; they must have good design, with repeatable tests, including in the tools you buy.

slides.title: SOC Tooling & Architecture Overview | Key Security Technologies

texts.content: A SOC relies on integrated tools and platforms to detect, investigate, and respond to threats efficiently.

content: EDR/XDR (Endpoint Detection & Response / Extended Detection & Response): Endpoint and cross-layer visibility
Network Security Tools: IDS/IPS, NDR, firewalls for real-time network monitoring
Threat Intelligence Platforms (TIP): Enrich alerts with actionable threat data
SOAR (Security Orchestration, Automation, and Response): Automates repetitive tasks and workflows

texts.content: Integrated tooling ensures faster detection, coordinated response, and continuous improvement of security operations.

slides.title: Threat Intelligence in the SOC | Using TI for Proactive Defense

texts.content: Threat intelligence (TI) helps the SOC anticipate attacks and enrich alerts with context.

content: Tactical TI: Indicators of compromise (IOCs) for immediate response
Operational TI: Understanding attacker methods and campaigns
Strategic TI: Trends, risks, and long-term threat planning
Integration: Feed TI into SIEM, SOAR, and detection rules

texts.content: Actionable threat intelligence turns raw data into informed decisions, improving detection and response efficiency.

slides.title: Incident Response Foundations | SOC Incident Management

texts.content: Incident response ensures organized, fast, and effective handling of security events.

content: Preparation: the most important step -> training, playbooks, process
Identification & Classification: Detect and categorize incidents by severity
Containment & Eradication: Stop the threat and remove its impact
Recovery: Restore systems and data safely
Lessons Learned: Update playbooks, rules, and processes

texts.content: A structured incident response reduces damage, accelerates recovery, and strengthens future SOC defenses.

slides.title: SOC Challenges & Best Practices | Improving Security Operations

texts.content:
SOC teams face common challenges that impact efficiency and effectiveness.
Key Challenges:

content: Resource constraints: Limited skilled personnel and time to build an effective defense
Alert fatigue: High volume of false positives
Coverage gaps: Missing visibility across systems or cloud services
Take time to build a real and effective defense
Automation & Orchestration: Reduce manual work and response time
Continuous Improvement: Use metrics, purple teaming, and lessons learned
Prioritization & Intelligence: Focus on high-risk threats and actionable alerts

texts.content: A well-optimized SOC balances technology, processes, and people to stay ahead of evolving cyber threats.

slides.title: Core Security Tools: Capabilities, Limits & SOC Impact
Firewalls in Cybersecurity: Benefits, Limits, and Common Misconceptions

content: Centralized control of network traffic (inbound and outbound).
Can filter based on IP, port, protocol, and application rules.
Helps protect against unauthorized external access.
Useful for network segmentation to reduce attack surface.
Cannot detect malicious activity already inside allowed traffic.
Misconfigurations can create false positives or block legitimate traffic.
Managing complex rules can be challenging in dynamic or cloud environments.

slides.title: Firewalls in Cybersecurity: Benefits, Limits, and Common Misconceptions

content: Only sees traffic that passes through it; cannot see endpoint behavior or encrypted payloads.
Cannot prevent attacks coming from inside the network.
Security depends on rule quality and timely updates.
Believing that a firewall can stop all attacks, including internal or insider threats.
Instead of relying on a firewall to detect or block malware uploads.

slides.title: Antivirus & Endpoint Protection (EPP): Benefits, Limits, and Common Misconceptions

content: Protects endpoints from known malware and viruses.
Uses heuristic and behavioral analysis to detect unknown threats.
Centralized management for updates and policy enforcement.
Can block malicious files before they execute and provide endpoint visibility.
Relatively low false positives, reducing unnecessary alerts.
Limited effectiveness against advanced persistent threats (APT) or targeted attacks.
Can impact endpoint performance if misconfigured.
Requires constant updates and tuning to maintain high detection rates.
Limited granularity in configuration, restricting fine-tuned control.
Cannot guarantee detection of sophisticated attacks or in-memory exploits.
Cannot prevent lateral movement across the network on its own.
Effectiveness depends on correct configuration and policy enforcement.
Struggles to detect malicious activity when attackers use legitimate admin tools or system binaries (LOLBins).
Basic malware protection for workstations and servers.
Believing it can stop all attacks, including sophisticated, targeted, or fileless malware.

slides.title: IDS & IPS in Cybersecurity: Detection, Prevention, Limits and SOC Essentials

content: Detects suspicious or malicious network patterns (signatures, anomalies).
Provides visibility on attacks such as scans, exploits, protocol abuses.
IPS can actively block known malicious traffic.
Helps detect attacks bypassing basic firewall filtering.
Signature-based detection misses unknown or obfuscated attacks.
Encrypted traffic drastically reduces visibility.
Limited efficiency against advanced or lateral-movement techniques.

slides.title: IDS & IPS in Cybersecurity: Detection, Prevention, Limits and SOC Essentials

content: Cannot see internal traffic or workstation-to-workstation communications.
Considering IDS a source of complete visibility, including internal traffic.
Treating IPS as a "set and forget" universal protection.
Detecting exploit attempts, scans, brute-force attacks, protocol anomalies.
Monitoring exposed zones (DMZ, internet-facing applications).
Adding deep-inspection capabilities on top of firewall rules.
Tracking repeated malicious connections or external probing.

slides.title: Endpoint Detection & Response (EDR): Advanced Threat Detection, Response & SOC Integration

content: Continuous endpoint monitoring: processes, files, registry, network connections.
Detects suspicious behavior, including fileless malware, LOLBins, and lateral movement.
Provides detailed forensic data for incident investigation and root-cause analysis.
Supports automated or semi-automated containment (quarantine, kill process, isolate device).
Requires agent deployment on endpoints; coverage gaps if agents are missing or disabled.
Resource-intensive: may impact performance
Advanced attackers can bypass EDR
Dependent on proper tuning: too loose → missed threats, too strict → false positives.
High alert volume

slides.title: Endpoint Detection & Response (EDR): Advanced Threat Detection, Response & SOC Integration

content: Limited visibility on network attacks
Detects suspicious activity after it occurs, so potential impact may have already happened.
Detecting unknown malware, ransomware, and lateral movement within the network.
Investigating alerts and providing detailed forensic evidence for incidents.
Containing compromised endpoints quickly to prevent further spread.

slides.title: Network Detection & Response (NDR): Monitoring, Threat Detection & SOC Insights

content: Provides network-wide visibility, including east-west traffic and encrypted flows.
Detects anomalies, lateral movement, command-and-control activity, and unusual protocol behavior.
Complements EDR by detecting threats that don't execute on endpoints.
Supports investigation with detailed network telemetry.
Limited detection of attacks inside endpoints before network activity occurs.
Encrypted traffic may reduce full visibility without TLS inspection.
May not provide actionable response beyond alerting or network quarantine.

slides.title: Network Detection & Response (NDR): Monitoring, Threat Detection & SOC Insights

content: Blind spots exist if NDR sensors are not deployed on all critical network segments.
Provides post-factum detection: alerts often after malicious network activity is underway.
Detecting lateral movement, suspicious beaconing, and command-and-control traffic.
Monitoring network segments where endpoint coverage is limited or missing.
Providing additional context for SOC analysts during threat hunts.

slides.title: Security Information & Event Management (SIEM): Centralized Monitoring, Correlation & Threat Detection

content: Centralizes and normalizes logs from all IT and security systems.
Supports dashboards, alerting, and reporting for SOC analysts.
Enables historical analysis and forensic investigation of security incidents.
Supports event correlation rules to identify patterns across multiple sources.
Typically not real-time; alerting depends on log collection interval and processing.
High alert volume can overwhelm SOC analysts if correlation rules are poorly tuned.
Cannot block or prevent attacks; purely detective.
Complex deployment and maintenance, especially in dynamic, complex or large environments.

slides.title: Security Information & Event Management (SIEM): Centralized Monitoring, Correlation & Threat Detection

content: Alerts are only as good as the logs collected; missing logs → blind spots.
Limited by latency: attacks can progress before detection due to log collection intervals.
SOC must implement correlation rules manually; achieving meaningful detection often takes years of tuning and refinement.
Must manage alert fatigue and group related alerts when the SIEM produces high volumes or low-quality signals.
Thinking SIEM replaces endpoint or network monitoring; it only correlates the data already collected.
Expecting SIEM to block attacks, even when integrated with SOAR.
Centralized logging and reporting for SOC visibility.
Identifying patterns and trends across multiple sources over time.
Investigating security incidents and reconstructing timelines.

slides.title: Threat Intelligence Platform (TIP): Collect, Analyze & Operationalize Threat Data

content: Centralizes threat intelligence from multiple sources: feeds, open source, commercial, internal indicators.
Normalizes and enriches threat data for SOC consumption.
Provides context for alerts: IOCs (IPs, domains, URLs, file hashes, TTPs).
Facilitates sharing intelligence across teams and trusted partners.
Only as good as the quality and relevance of threat feeds.
Risk of irrelevant or outdated indicators being acted on if not managed carefully.
Unknown IOCs or threats that change indicators will not be detected.

slides.title: Threat Intelligence Platform (TIP): Collect, Analyze & Operationalize Threat Data

content: IOCs based detections
Providing contextual information for alerts.
Conducting threat hunting based on known attacker TTPs.

slides.title: WAF (Web Application Firewall): Protecting Web Applications from Attacks

content: Filters and blocks HTTP/HTTPS attacks.
Protects exposed web applications from common exploitation attempts.
Useful for virtual patching when the application cannot be fixed immediately.
Ineffective against logic flaws.
Can be bypassed with obfuscation or non-standard payloads.
Not useful for detecting attacks on internal services

slides.title: WAF (Web Application Firewall): Protecting Web Applications from Attacks

content: Deploying it as a replacement for secure development or code reviews.
Protecting web applications from common attack vectors (OWASP)
Providing additional telemetry for SOC investigations.

slides.title: Data Loss Prevention (DLP): Protecting Sensitive Data on Endpoint & Network

content: Monitors and controls sensitive data movement on endpoints, network, and cloud.
Detects and block unauthorized data transfers: emails, USB devices, file uploads, cloud storage.
Provides audit logs for investigations and reporting.
May generate false positives if policies are too broad.
Limited effectiveness against encrypted traffic or obfuscated data.
Can be bypassed by sophisticated users.

slides.title: Data Loss Prevention (DLP): Protecting Sensitive Data on Endpoint & Network

content: Only detects actions defined in policies; unknown data types or formats may pass undetected.
Endpoint DLP relies on agents; if agents are disabled or circumvented, protection is lost.
Network DLP requires proper placement to monitor traffic; blind spots can exist.
Assuming DLP replaces user awareness and good practices; it's a technical control, not a human behavior fix.
Preventing accidental or malicious exfiltration of sensitive data.
Supporting SOC investigations into data exfiltration events.

slides.title: Extended Detection & Response (XDR): One Tool to Rule Them All ?

content: XDR aims to unify EDR, NDR, DLP, SIEM, TIP, and more under a single platform.
Designed to simplify SOC operations and provide centralized visibility.
Reality: most XDR solutions today attempt to do everything but do each component partially.
Can lead to superficial detection, alert fatigue, and gaps in coverage if relied on as a standalone solution.
Effective use requires still relying on specialized tools and skilled analysts.

slides.title: UEBA (User & Entity Behavior Analytics): Detecting Anomalies Through Behavior

content: UEBA analyzes user and entity behavior patterns to detect unusual activity.
Useful for spotting insider threats, compromised accounts, and lateral movement.
Reality check: UEBA can produce false positives, needs time to learn "normal" behavior, and is not effective on its own.

slides.title: Additional Detection Tools: Specialized Sensors Across Hosts, Network & Cloud

content: HIDS (Host Intrusion Detection System): monitors host-level events: file integrity, logs, configuration changes.
NIDS (Network Intrusion Detection System): inspects network packets to detect known signatures or suspicious patterns.
NTA (Network Traffic Analysis): focuses on behavioral and statistical analysis of network flows.
Wireless IDS (WIDS): monitors Wi-Fi activity for rogue access points, suspicious clients, and RF-based attacks.
Email Security Gateways: filters phishing, malware, spoofed domains, malicious attachments.
Secure Web Gateway (SWG) / Proxy Monitoring: inspects outbound web traffic: URL filtering, file inspection, SSL/TLS inspection.

slides.title: SOAR Platforms for SOC Operations: Orchestration & Automated Response

content: Designed to automate SOC workflows, enrich alerts, and execute response playbooks.
Helps SOC teams reduce manual workload, accelerate triage, and standardize responses.
Extremely useful for repetitive tasks: enrichment, blocking IPs, disabling accounts, notifications.
Reduces MTTR (Mean Time To Respond) when properly implemented.
Automates routine SOC tasks → frees analyst time for real investigations.
Requires high-quality detection upstream → no good input, no good output.
Complex to integrate across heterogeneous environments.
Requires constant maintenance of playbooks, connectors, API keys, and workflows, the SOC must manually integrate every input and output tool.
Risk of over-automation → blocking legitimate users or systems if rules are too aggressive.

slides.title: SOAR Platforms for SOC Operations: Orchestration & Automated Response

content: Deploying SOAR as a "magic fix" for alert fatigue instead of fixing root causes.
Thinking SOAR will improve detection quality.
Believing SOAR can correlate alerts or improve detection logic, it does not analyze or correlate signals; it only automates actions based on existing alerts.
Alert enrichment (WHOIS, TI lookup, sandboxing).
Automated containment (isolate host, revoke tokens, disable user).
Workflow automation (ticket creation, notifications, triage templates).

slides.title: Cybersecurity Vulnerability Scanning: Tools for Exposure and Risk Identification

content: Scan systems, applications, configurations, and software dependenciesfor known vulnerabilities.
Provide risk scoring (CVSS, EPSS), remediation guidance, and asset visibility.
Essential for continuous hardening, hygiene, and reducing attack surface.
Primarily used by internal SOC / internal security teams.
Scanners identify potential weaknesses, not ongoing exploitation.
Helps prioritize patching based on severity and business impact.

slides.title: Cybersecurity Vulnerability Scanning: Tools for Exposure and Risk Identification

content: Limited against zero-days, logic flaws, or application-specific bugs.
Maintaining a vulnerability management program.
Tracking remediation progress across teams.
Assuming scanning alone improves security, without patching, scans mean nothing.

slides.title: Detection Tool Internals: Exploring Mechanisms and Techniques
Hashing and Fuzzy Hashes: Core File-Based Detection

content: Cryptographic Hashes: MD5, SHA-1, SHA-256 for identifying known files
Format-Specific Hashes: imphash (import hash) for PE files to detect variants: bypass by adding Win32 API functions usages
Fuzzy Hashes: SSDEEP, TLSH to identify similar or slightly modified files: bypass by adding data or padding (length based)
Use Case: Quickly verify file integrity and detect known malware

texts.content: Hashing is a foundational detection vulnerability_scanning.jpgmechanism, but alone it cannot catch modern malware variants, complementary heuristics and behavioral monitoring are required.

slides.title: Heuristic Analysis: Detecting Suspicious File Patterns

content: File Metadata Analysis: Inspect PE (Windows) and ELF (Linux) executables, timestamps, imports/exports, embedded macros: potential bypass with headers modifications
Text/File Parsing: Analyze PDFs (JavaScript), Office files (VBA), scripts for suspicious patterns: potential bypass with encoding
Entropy Analysis: Detect compressed or encrypted content that may hide malware: bypass with encoding
Use Case: Identify previously unknown malware or modified files that evade signature-based detection
Limitations: May generate false positives; cannot always pinpoint precise threat origin

texts.content: Heuristic analysis strengthens detection by examining file structure, content, and entropy, allowing the discovery of hidden or modified malware beyond simple hash checks.

slides.title: Signature Languages: Regex & Yara for Malware Detection

content: Regex: Pattern matching and text parsing for suspicious strings, macros, or script content
Yara: Advanced pattern matching tool; can scan files, memory, and processes for complex malware indicators
Power of Yara: Supports modular rules, conditional logic, and metadata; widely used in EDR and threat hunting
Limitation: Purely signature-based

texts.content: Yara extends simple regex with powerful, flexible rules that allow detection of sophisticated malware, including in-memory threats, but still relies on pre-defined signatures.

slides.title: File Monitoring: fanotify, inotify, and Minifilter Drivers

content:
inotify (Linux):
  • Monitors filesystem events on specific files or directories
  • Non-blocking, low overhead, no root required
  • Based on VFS, ideal for general file monitoring

fanotify (Linux):
  • Can block or allow access to files, requires root privileges
  • Higher overhead, monitors entire mounts
  • Suitable for security enforcement where blocking is needed

Minifilter Drivers (Windows):
  • Kernel-level monitoring of file operations
  • Requires signed kernel module
  • Tracks disk actions like create, read, write, delete

texts.content: File monitoring provides granular visibility into filesystem-level operations, differentiating between non-blocking observers (inotify/ETW) and blocking enforcement (fanotify/Minifilter).

slides.title: Linux System Interfaces: ProcFS, SysFS, Netlink, and eBPF for Kernel-Level Monitoring

content: ProcFS: Provides access to process information and system statistics from user space
SysFS: Exposes kernel objects and hardware info for monitoring and configuration
Netlink: Kernel-to-user communication for networking events and monitoring
eBPF: Executes custom programs safely in the kernel for event tracing, monitoring, and security enforcement

texts.content: Linux system interfaces enable deep visibility into processes, hardware, and kernel events, forming the foundation for advanced detection tools without modifying the kernel.

slides.title: Windows Event Monitoring: ETW, ETW-TI, and WMI for SOC Visibility

content: ETW (Event Tracing for Windows): Kernel and application-level event logging for detailed system activity
ETW-TI: Threat Intelligence integration with ETW events for enriched detection

WMI (Windows Management Instrumentation):
  • Queries system and application data; relies on ETW underneath
  • Very simple to attach callbacks
  • Deeply integrated with Windows, .NET, and PowerShell
Key Usage: Collects detailed telemetry for monitoring processes, user actions, and system changes

texts.content: Windows event monitoring provides SOC teams with granular visibility into system and application behavior, forming the backbone of detection and correlation in EDR and SIEM solutions.

slides.title: AMSI: Antimalware Scan Interface for Runtime Malware Detection

content: What is AMSI: Windows API that allows applications and scripts to request malware scanning from the system's antivirus engine
Language Agnostic: Any language can call AMSI (PowerShell, VBScript, .NET, etc.), its userland API (bypass by memory patching)

How to use:
  1. The runtime tokenizes, parses, builds AST, and resolves aliases
  2. After preprocessing, the language requests a scan from AMSI
  3. Scans can occur on execution, on new block definitions, or on-demand
Integration: Provides runtime protection without modifying the underlying antivirus engine

texts.content: AMSI enables runtime malware scanning by allowing languages to submit preprocessed code for detection, bridging scripts and antivirus engines for enhanced SOC visibility.

slides.title: Logging Techniques for Detection: /var/log, ETW, Sysmon, and auditd

content:
Linux Logging (/var/log):
  • Most logs are line-by-line text files, read incrementally by process
  • Binary logs exist (journalctl, wtmp/utmp/btmp) and are harder to parse
  • Tools like auditd provide structured, configurable logging for security monitoring

Windows Logging (ETW):
  • Event Tracing for Windows enables real-time event registration, more reliable than parsing .evtx files
  • Allows detection of system, application, and security events
  • Sysmon enhances ETW with detailed process, network, and file activity logs, easier to parse and configure than raw ETW
Sysmon (Windows): Extended system monitoring, logs process creation, network connections, and file changes

texts.content: These logging mechanisms provide the raw event streams that detection tools consume; understanding their format, access method, and incremental update behavior is essential to implement detection at the system level.

slides.title: Sigma & Rule Languages for Detection

content: Core Idea: Standardized, human-readable detection rules across platforms
Purpose: Translate detection logic into a universal format usable on multiple SIEMs and log sources

Mechanism:
  • Convert log events into structured patterns
  • Translate platform-specific log fields into a normalized schema
  • Rules can be shared and reused across environments

Limitations:
  • Requires mapping log fields to a standardized schema
  • Effectiveness limited by the quality and richness of log data available

texts.content: Sigma enables structured detection across diverse log sources, but mapping and log completeness are critical for accurate detection.

slides.title: Kernel Modules & Syscall Tracing (Linux) & ELAM (Windows)

content: Core Idea: Deep visibility by intercepting system activity directly in the kernel

Linux Kernel Modules for Detection:
  • Implement syscall hooking or syscall table redirection to monitor process, file, and network actions
  • Very difficult for malware to kill or bypass when properly protected

Windows ELAM (Early Launch Anti-Malware):
  • Kernel-level anti-malware driver loaded before all other drivers
  • Ensures malicious kernel modules are blocked before initialization
  • ELAM drivers must be signed by Microsoft

Windows Drivers:
  • Kernel callbacks (process, image, thread)
  • Registry callbacks
  • Minifilters
  • Object Callbacks (HANDLE)
  • ETW
  • WFP Callouts (Windows Filtering Platform, network)
Kernel faults → system crashes
Requires correct signing (Windows)

texts.content: Kernel-level monitoring (Linux modules, Windows ELAM) provides the strongest and earliest detection capability, resistant to userland bypass techniques, but comes with high complexity and strict signing requirements.

slides.title: Honeypots: Core Principles & Best Practices

texts.content: Definition & Scope: A honeypot is not only a fake vulnerable system, it can be a:

content: user account: (local, domain, email, social networks like LinkedIn)
file: (filesystem, SMB share, SharePoint item, web-accessible PDF)
script: containing credentials or other artifacts
service/port
URL path or embedded link

texts.content:
Purpose: Attract, detect, and analyze malicious behavior in locations where no legitimate activity should ever occur. Provide high-confidence SOC signals with minimal noise.
Key Success Factors: The most effective honeypots are often custom-built, mimicking realistic vulnerabilities or artifacts from the existing environment (internal naming conventions, plausible accounts, believable file paths, etc.).
Operational Considerations:

content: A well-designed honeypot should generate zero false positives-any interaction is suspicious.
Do not disclose honeypots internally; exposure invalidates their detection value.

slides.title: Advanced Threat Intelligence Formats (MISP / STIX) for SOC Automation

content: Role: Structured representation of IOCs, TTPs, relationships, campaigns, and infrastructures; seamless integration into TIP/SIEM/EDR/SOAR/CTI workflows.
MISP: Object-based model (Events/Attributes), optimized for high-volume IOC ingestion, normalization, scoring, and operational distribution.
STIX 2.x: JSON cyber-object model, optimized for graph-based context, linking indicators, behaviors, and threat activity, preferred by hunters for relational visibility.
Limits: Highly perishable IOCs (hash/IP/domain churn), limited coverage of unknown/emerging threats, and significant maintenance effort (cleaning, deduplication, validation).

texts.content: MISP optimizes IOC ingestion, while STIX provides a relationship-driven graph model ideal for hunting and contextual analysis.

slides.title: Advanced Email Authentication Mechanisms (SPF / DKIM / DMARC)

content: SPF: DNS-based validation of authorized sending IPs; prevents basic envelope spoofing but fragile with forwarding.
DKIM: Cryptographic signing of headers/body; ensures integrity and domain-level authenticity, unaffected by relays.
DMARC: Alignment check (SPF/DKIM ↔ From header) + policy enforcement (none/quarantine/reject) + feedback loops.
Limits: No protection against internal phishing, compromised accounts, or malicious content (attachments/links) bypassing authentication controls.

texts.content: SPF and DKIM provide authentication signals, while DMARC enforces policy and alignment, but none mitigate internal phishing or payload-based attacks.

slides.title: SOC Detection Engineering Methodology: Building High-Quality Detection Rules
Understanding the Attack Scenario

content: Detection priorities come from Governance (risk, policy, compliance).
Detection topics come from CTI (what attackers use).
Both define what must be covered, not how the attack actually occurs.
CTI knows what attackers use (TTP, tools), but not how attackers actually implement the attack.
Governance imposes requirements without technical context.
SOC often writes rules without a complete scenario → weak, noisy, or blind detections.

texts.content: Methodology: Read available documentation, Answer core questions: Where does this scenario occur in the attack flow ? Why would the attacker perform this action ? At which stage of the attack does it appear ? Use this understanding to build a clear mental model before writing any detection rule.

slides.title: Selecting the Right Detection Tool

texts.content:
Why this step exists
Each detection approach has different constraints:

content: Some do not work for certain scenarios
Some are too limited
Some are less secure (e.g., bypass, termination, configuration changes, identity spoofing, network requirements, etc.).
Others lack efficiency or responsiveness
Some take significantly longer to implement
Many SOC teams choose a method by habit or urgency rather than by suitability.

This leads to choosing approaches that are misaligned with the scenario, resulting in reduced visibility, lower trustworthiness from a security standpoint, degraded efficiency, and unnecessary losses in time and budget during implementation.

texts.content: Methodology: Choose the detection method that makes the most sense for the scenario: the one that offers the right visibility, the best long-term efficiency, and the lowest operational cost.

slides.title: Writing the Initial Detection Rule

content: The first version of a rule is not meant to be perfect, it's meant to translate the scenario into an initial detection hypothesis.
This draft reveals what is missing, unclear, or unrealistic before deeper refinement.
Many SOC teams write rules without a clear scenario, leading to noisy, incomplete, or irrelevant detections.
Others copy existing rules without understanding their assumptions, creating misaligned or fragile detections.

texts.content: Methodology: Start with a simple, scenario-based rule to capture the core behavior you aim to detect. As a first step, you can rely on public rules or AI-generated rules to identify key elements and outline the scenario before writing the final detection rule.

slides.title: Identifying Potential False Positives

content: A detection rule is useless if it triggers constantly on legitimate activity.
Identifying potential false positives early prevents writing rules that will overwhelm analysts and never reach production.
Lack of business context leads SOC teams to misinterpret normal behaviors as malicious.
Time pressure often prevents analysts from deeply understanding how a TTP works at a low level, and from imagining potential false positives before creating or testing the rule.

texts.content: Methodology: Understand the draft rule thoroughly to identify all known, legitimate system behaviors that could match it. Avoid "tuning" or adjusting a rule that is still conceptually flawed, the draft stage is meant to challenge assumptions, not to prematurely optimize.

slides.title: Distinguishing True Positives from False Positives

content: To design an accurate detection rule, you must clearly understand what makes the malicious behavior different from legitimate activity.
Without this step, the final rule remains either too broad.
SOC teams often observe matches without fully understanding the execution logic behind them.
Analysts may assume "it matches = it's good detection"

texts.content: Methodology: Break down the malicious scenario into its fundamental behaviors and conditions. Break down the legitimate behaviors that also trigger the draft rule. Compare both sides to extract clear discriminators.

slides.title: Identifying Bypass Techniques

content: A detection rule must account for the ways an attacker could modify their behavior to avoid being detected.
Some detection concepts have structural limitations, and documenting them is essential for Incident Response and Governance to properly assess risk and prioritize future improvements.
SOC teams often evaluate rules only against the "expected" attack, not against variants or stealthier executions.
Many assumptions are made about how an attacker "should" behave, leading to blind spots.

texts.content: Methodology: Break the draft rule into all its individual parameters and conditions. For each parameter and condition, determine whether an attacker could alter it while still performing a malicious action.

slides.title: Identifying Missing Scenarios

content: A solid detection must cover all realistic ways an attacker could achieve the targeted behavior
Missing scenarios create blind spots that attackers can exploit without triggering any alert.
Analysts often rely only on previously seen attacks or existing rules, leading to a fixed and narrow view of the scenario.
Lack of creativity and limited technical exploration prevent identification of alternative paths.
Without actively searching for missing variants, many angles remain undetected.

texts.content: Methodology: Start from the target behavior, identify all possible ways to reach that same behavior. Break down the underlying technology, protocol, or method to understand every valid interaction or workflow it allows.

slides.title: Rewriting the Optimized Rule

content: After understanding false positives, true positives, bypasses, and missing scenarios, the initial draft rule must be redesigned from scratch.
The goal is to build a clean, reliable, and conceptually sound detection, not a tuned version of the flawed draft.
Many SOC teams adjust the original rule instead of rebuilding a proper detection logic, keeping its weaknesses.
Without integrating all previous findings, the final rule remains incomplete, fragile, or limited.
Pressure to "deploy fast" often results in rules that only partially cover the scenario.
Start a new detection design, based on the discriminators identified earlier (true vs. false positives).
Integrate all insights from the bypass analysis: ensure the rule covers attacker behaviors that cannot be easily altered.
Incorporate missing scenarios or create a rule for all valid paths leading to the malicious outcome.

slides.title: Testing and Validating the Detection Rule

content: A rule is only reliable if it consistently works over time.
Testing ensures correctness, stability, and maintainability, even when the SI or the rule evolves.
Many SOC teams deploy rules without proper testing, leading to silent failures.
Manual testing is incomplete, non-repeatable, and quickly abandoned.
Changes in the infrastructure often break rules without anyone noticing.

texts.content: Methodology: Create unit tests for every part of the logic: test each condition individually (each AND, each OR, and all combinations) with intentionally crafted logs. Create functional tests to validate the full scenario: replay or simulate the malicious behavior in the real SI, verify end-to-end detection, from log ingestion to alert generation, run these functional tests every 3 months to ensure the rule still works.

slides.title: Documentation Requirements for High-Quality Detection Rules

texts.content:
4. Identifying Potential False Positives: Document all legitimate behaviors that may trigger the draft rule, it's required for rule redesign, IR awareness, and operational risk assessment.
5. Distinguishing True vs. False Positives: Document the discriminators, it's required to understand the final rule logic.
6. Identifying Bypass Techniques: Document all bypass possibilities and conceptual limitations it's critical for Governance and IR to understand residual risks and plan future improvements.
7. Identifying Missing Scenarios: Document all alternative paths leading to the same malicious outcome to ensures the final rule covers all relevant variants and avoids blind spots.
9. Testing the Rule Document unit tests, functional tests, and validation results to ensures repeatability, long-term reliability, and operational trust in the rule.

slides.title: Summary of the Detection Engineering Methodology

content: Understand the Attack Scenario: Build a clear picture of the attacker's goal, context, and behavior.
Select the Appropriate Detection Method: Choose the approach that offers the right visibility and long-term efficiency.
Write the Initial Draft Rule: Create a hypothesis-based rule to explore the scenario.
Identify Potential False Positives: Map all legitimate behaviors that may incorrectly trigger detection.
Distinguish True vs. False Positives: Extract the discriminators that differentiate malicious from legitimate activity.
Identify Bypass Techniques: Analyze how attackers could alter their behavior to avoid detection.
Identify Missing Scenarios: Explore all possible paths leading to the same malicious outcome.
Rewrite the Optimized Rule: Rebuild a clean, accurate rule using all insights gathered.
Test and Validate the Rule: Use automated unit and functional tests to ensure reliability over time.

slides.title: Practical Example: How a Poorly Designed Detection Rule Fails
From Attack Scenario to a Faulty Draft Rule (Typical SOC Mistake)

texts.content:
SOC teams are asked to detect "PowerShell executing malware on the network."
Typical SOC workflow (too fast, too shallow):

content: Immediate choice: use the SIEM.
Immediate action: write a rule.
No deep analysis of the scenario or PowerShell behavior.

texts.content: Many SOCs produce weak rules because they rush into writing them without understanding the scenario or its technical diversity.

slides.title: Why This Detection Rule Completely Fails (FP, Bypass, Missing Scenarios)

texts.content: False Positives (Operational Noise): Hypervisors using PowerShell with -EncodedCommand to query WMI. Bypass Techniques (Attacker Variations Within the Same Behavior)

content: Using PowerShell aliases like iwr.
Using LoLBins inside PowerShell (bitsadmin, certutil)
Re-implementing HTTP through a socket in PowerShell.
Malware format without file written: Shellcode (execution in memory), PowerShell (IEX), C# (Add-Type)
Using another protocol such as an SMB mount.
Injecting the payload through PowerShell STDIN, leaving no command-line trace.

slides.title: Evaluation Criteria for Detection Rule Assignments
Core Evaluation

content: Justify why the selected detection tool or approach was used.
Consider efficiency, visibility, long-term maintainability.
Correctly implement a basic detection rule.
Show understanding of the scenario.
Detect legitimate activities that trigger the rule.
Explain reasoning and provide examples.

slides.title: Advanced Evaluation

texts.content: Differentiating True Positives vs. False Positives (if applicable): Demonstrate ability to distinguish between legitimate matches and malicious matches.
Identification of Potential Bypasses or Alternative Scenarios (if applicable): Document how attackers could evade the rule.

content: Rule minimizes or eliminates false positives and false negatives.
Consider coverage of all identified scenarios and correct design logic.

slides.title: Optional / Bonus Points

content: Unit tests for each condition (AND, OR, keywords).
Functional tests simulating the attack scenario.
How to block this type of attack in a SOC context.
How to perform an incident response for the detected attack.

slides.title: Exam Logistics and Evaluation Process
Exam Workflow Overview

content: Students know the required setup in advance.
Each group must prepare one VM (Linux or Windows depending on the scenario assigned).
Morning: each group receives its attack scenario.

All day:
  • Deploy and configure their detection tool.
  • Write the initial detection rule.
  • Identify false positives and false negatives.
  • Produce the final corrected rule.
Evening: submit the report (one per group) with final rule and bullet-point reasoning for each methodological step

slides.title: Evaluation & Oral Defense

content: Instructor runs tests on each group's infrastructure: common false positives and crafted false negatives
These tests establish the baseline score for the group.
This evaluates the quality and robustness of the final rule.
Each student is examined individually, even though rule creation was done in groups.

Objectives of the oral evaluation:
  • Verify understanding of every step of the 9-stage methodology.
  • Assess ability to justify decisions: why this tool ? why this logic ? why this improvement ?
  • Confirm that each member contributed and understood the final rule.

slides.title: Exam Workflow: Organization & Best Practices

content: 30 min: Form groups and plan the workflow.

3 h: Two students build the infrastructure; two pairs each write a baseline detection rule, identify false positives, bypasses, missing scenarios, and rewrite an improved version (everything documented for the report).
Infra team deploys all rules and executes scenarios, bypass attempts, and false positives.
The two other groups review each other's rules, identify gaps, weaknesses, and improvement points (fully documented).
Merge findings into a single optimized rule combining strengths and reducing limitations.
Submit the final report and take a system snapshot to preserve a stable state for the exam.

slides.title: Hands-On SOC Detection Engineering Exercises: High-Quality Rule Design & Adversary Simulation
Windows Startup Payload Execution - Attack Scenario

content: Attacker Goal: Establish a persistent foothold by ensuring malicious code automatically executes after system reboot or user logon.
Context: Startup locations in Windows are frequently abused because they allow silent, recurring execution without requiring elevated privileges.

slides.title: Tools, Telemetry, and Initial Draft Rule

content: Required Visibility & Telemetry Sources: Endpoint instrumentation capable of tracking file creation, registry modifications, and process execution in startup-related paths, Tools providing historical context (timeline, baselining, user activity correlation)
Recommended Tools: EDR offering granular process and registry auditing

Rule: 
detection:
    files_in_startup:
        EventID: 4663   # File creation
        ObjectPath|contains:
            - "\Startup\"
    registry_autorun:
        EventID: 4657   # Registry value creation/modification
        ObjectName|contains:
            - "Software\\Microsoft\\Windows\\CurrentVersion\\Run"
    condition: files_in_startup OR registry_autorun

slides.title: False Positives, Bypass Paths & Missing Cases

texts.content:
False positive: configuration on update (registry key: RunOnce), any file in a startup directory.
Bypass: Startup folder modification (registry key: "HKEY_CURRENT_USER\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Explorer\User Shell Folders", "HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Explorer\User Shell Folders")
Missing scenario:

content: Task scheduler
Services (new service, modification or Hijacking)
DLL Hijacking on startup program (and COM Hijacking)
PE injection on startup program
AppInit registry key (HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion\Windows[AppInit_DLLs])
WMI using persistent Filter/Consumer
Kernel driver

slides.title: Optimized Rule Implementation

texts.content:
For this exercise, the optimized rule focuses exclusively on three scenarios: modifications to registry Run keys, file activity in Startup folders, and WMI permanent event subscriptions: 
detection:
    files_in_startup:
        EventID: 4663   # File creation
        ObjectPath|contains:
            - "C:\Users\*\AppData\Roaming\Microsoft\Windows\Start Menu\Programs\Startup"
            - "C:\ProgramData\Microsoft\Windows\Start Menu\Programs\Startup"
    registry_autorun:
        EventID: 4657   # Registry value creation/modification
        ObjectName|contains:
            - "Software\\Microsoft\\Windows\\CurrentVersion\\Run"
            - "SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Explorer\User Shell Folders"
	wmi_persistence_boot:
		EventID:
			- 5861   # WMI Event Filter Created/Modified
			- 5860   # WMI Event Consumer Created/Modified
			- 5862   # WMI Binding Created/Modified
		Operation|contains:
			- "create"
			- "modify"
		ClassName|contains:
			- "__EventFilter"
			- "CommandLineEventConsumer"
			- "ActiveScriptEventConsumer"
			- "FilterToConsumerBinding"
		# Optional: focusing on boot/logon-related triggers
		Query|contains:
			- "Win32_ComputerShutdownEvent"
			- "Win32_ComputerStartupEvent"
			- "Win32_LogonSession"
    condition: files_in_startup OR registry_autorun OR wmi_persistence_boot

slides.title: Credential Theft Techniques - Attack Scenario

texts.content:
Attacker Goal: Obtain valid user or administrator credentials to expand access, escalate privileges, or move laterally within the environment.
Context: Credential theft is a common phase in modern intrusions, as attackers rely heavily on harvesting authentication material instead of brute-forcing passwords. Tools and techniques target memory, authentication tokens, password stores, or API-based credential interfaces.

slides.title: Tools, Telemetry, and Initial Draft Rule

texts.content:
Required Visibility & Telemetry Sources: Endpoint telemetry capable of capturing object access attempts (process, files, ...).
Recommended Tools: EDR platforms with granular monitoring of handle requests, and security-related API calls.
Rule:
detection:
    # Suspicious access to LSASS or similar processes
    lsass_access:
        EventID: 4663
        ObjectName|contains:
            - "lsass.exe"
            - "lsa"
        AccessMask|contains:
            - "0x10"   # PROCESS_VM_READ-like permission
            - "0x20"

    # Unusual process requesting high-privilege memory access
    sensitive_handle_request:
        EventID: 4656
        ObjectName|contains:
            - "lsass.exe"
            - "sam"
            - "security"
        AccessMask|contains:
            - "0x10"
            - "0x20"

    # Suspicious duplication of tokens or privilege escalation behavior
    token_duplication:
        EventID: 4673
        PrivilegeList|contains:
            - "SeDebugPrivilege"
            - "SeTcbPrivilege"

    condition: lsass_access OR sensitive_handle_request OR token_duplication

slides.title: False Positives, Evasion Techniques, and Coverage Gaps

texts.content:
False positive: all access on object with "lsa" in the name
Bypass: other access mask with 0x10 bit set (0x30, 0xF0, ...)
Missing scenario:

content: Keylogger
Credentials stealer: system credentials, credentials protected by DPAPI, browser credentials, admin tools credentials, dev tools credentials, ...
Password manager exploits: unencrypted dump, get database file and steal secret key (PE Injection, replace executable file, DLL Hijacking), ...
Browser plugin (Pure JS or JS + executable)
Network sniffer // Proxy

slides.title: IAT Hooking on Windows - Attack Scenario

texts.content:
Attacker Goal: Alter the behavior of trusted processes by intercepting function calls and redirecting them to malicious code, enabling stealthy execution, data manipulation, or credential interception.
Context: IAT (Import Address Table) hooking is a technique where attackers modify the addresses of imported APIs inside a process's memory. Because many security-sensitive applications rely on predictable API calls, manipulating the IAT enables adversaries to hijack execution flow without creating new processes or injecting easily detectable payloads.

slides.title: Tools, Telemetry, and Initial Draft Rule

texts.content:
Required Visibility & Telemetry Sources: Endpoint visibility capable of monitoring process memory modifications, including write operations targeting module address ranges and DLL load events.
Recommended Tools: EDR platforms offering deep memory monitoring: module integrity checks, in-memory patch detection, API resolution monitoring.
Rule:
detection:
    suspicious_memory_write:
        EventID: 4656
        AccessMask|contains: "WRITE"
        ObjectName|contains:
            - ".dll"
            - "import"
            - "iat"

    unexpected_module_load:
        EventID: 7      # Module load (Sysmon)
        ImageLoaded|contains:
            - ".dll"
        Signed: false

    module_integrity_change:
        EventID: 11     # File or module tampering
        TargetFilename|contains:
            - ".dll"
            - ".exe"

    condition: suspicious_memory_write OR unexpected_module_load OR module_integrity_change

slides.title: False Positives, Evasion Techniques, and Coverage Gaps

texts.content:
False positive: debugger, application shimming, access handle on objects whose name contains "iat", all non-signed module imported, installers
Bypass: API hooking on images with any extension other than .dll when the "iat" or "import" words is not working.
Missing scenario:

slides.title: Refined Detection Logic and Validation Strategy

texts.content:
detection:
  iat_write_detected: IAT_Write_Detected() == true

  shim_not_loaded: Module_Is_Loaded("shim.dll") == false
  not_first_second: Time_Since_Process_Start() > 1s
  shim_loaded_via_ll: Module_Loaded_Via_LoadLibrary("shim.dll") == true

  shim_in_imports: Module_In_Imports("shim.dll") == true
  critical_functions_unused: NOT Module_Functions_Used("shim.dll", ["CriticalFunc1", "CriticalFunc2"]) 

  condition: |
    iat_write_detected AND (
        shim_not_loaded OR
        not_first_second OR
        shim_loaded_via_ll OR
        shim_in_imports OR
        critical_functions_unused
    )

action:
  - trigger_alert("Suspicious IAT write detected or shim.dll suspicious usage")

slides.title: DCSync Attack - Scenario Overview

texts.content:
Attacker Goal: Extract password hashes, Kerberos secrets, and domain replication data by impersonating a legitimate Domain Controller, enabling full domain compromise or long-term credential abuse.
Context: A DCSync attack abuses the Directory Replication Service Remote Protocol (DRSR). Instead of dumping credentials locally, the attacker requests them directly from Active Directory as if it were performing legitimate replication. This technique is stealthy because it does not require code execution on a Domain Controller.

slides.title: Tools, Telemetry, and Initial Draft Rule

texts.content:
Required Visibility & Telemetry Sources: Active Directory security logs capturing replication-related operations, network monitoring and system telemetry.
Recommended Tools: A SIEM platform capable of correlating multiple data sources simultaneously
Rule:
detection:
    replication_from_non_dc:
        EventID: 4662
        ObjectType|contains: "DS-Replication"
        SubjectUserName|not_contains: "$"   # non-DC accounts usually lack $ suffix
        AccessMask|contains:
            - "0x100"   # Replicating Directory Changes
            - "0x200"   # Replicating Directory Changes All

    unexpected_source_host:
        EventID: 1644
        SourceIPAddress|not_in:
            - known_domain_controllers

    privileged_account_usage:
        EventID: 4673
        PrivilegeList|contains:
            - "SeEnableDelegationPrivilege"

    condition: replication_from_non_dc OR unexpected_source_host OR privileged_account_usage

slides.title: False Positives, Evasion Techniques, and Coverage Gaps

texts.content:
False positive: all legit services using SeEnableDelegationPrivilege
Bypass: perform DCSync from an AD with the host account.
Missing scenario:

slides.title: Refined Detection Logic and Validation Strategy

content: Filter on event ID for AD synchronization or detect synchronization from network monitoring
Identify IP source and source port
Resolve the source host from the source IP
On the source host find the process from the source port
If it's not the legit process → trigger alert
Bonus: check local user, session and parent process start time.

slides.title: Payload Execution via EXCEL.EXE - Attack Scenario

texts.content:
Attacker Goal: Execute malicious code by abusing Microsoft Excel as a trusted application to bypass security controls, gain initial access, or run embedded payloads without raising immediate suspicion.
Context: Excel are highvalue targets for attackers because they are widely allowed in enterprise environments and often trusted by users.

slides.title: Tools, Telemetry, and Initial Draft Rule

texts.content:
Required Visibility & Telemetry Sources: Endpoint telemetry capturing process behaviors.
Recommended Tools: EDR capable of correlating process behaviours anomalies.
Rule:
detection:
    excel_spawning_process:
        EventID: 1      # Process creation (Sysmon)
        ParentImage|endswith: "\EXCEL.EXE"

    suspicious_child_process:
        Image|contains:
            - "cmd.exe"
            - "powershell.exe"
            - "wscript.exe"
            - "cscript.exe"
            - ".exe"

    unexpected_excel_location:
        ParentImage|equals:
            "C:\Program Files\Microsoft Office\root\Office16\EXCEL.EXE"

    condition: excel_spawning_process AND suspicious_child_process

slides.title: False Positives, Evasion Techniques, and Coverage Gaps

texts.content:
False positive: Excel can be multi-process, plugins, or features mapped to legitimate services (Power Query, Power Pivot), and sandboxed document openings (Protected View).
Bypass: scr files.
Missing scenario:

content: full malware in VBA (or load and execute instructions in memory)
XLL
Replace excel executable
PE injection

slides.title: Refined Detection Logic and Validation Strategy

texts.content:
detection:

  # ------------------------------------------------------------
  # 1. Excel doit etre le processus observe (full path)
  # ------------------------------------------------------------
  excel_proc:
    Image:
      - 'C:\Program Files\Microsoft Office
oot\Office16\EXCEL.EXE'
      - 'C:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft Office
oot\Office16\EXCEL.EXE'
      - 'C:\Program Files\Microsoft Office\Office16\EXCEL.EXE'
      - 'C:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft Office\Office16\EXCEL.EXE'

  # ------------------------------------------------------------
  # 2. Interdiction chargement d'un fichier XLL dans la ligne de commande
  # ------------------------------------------------------------
  xll_in_cmd:
    CommandLine|contains: '.xll'
  no_xll:
    condition: not xll_in_cmd

  # ------------------------------------------------------------
  # 3. Interdiction ouverture XLSM provenant d'Internet (MOTW)
  # MOTW vient d'un alternate data stream "Zone.Identifier"
  # ------------------------------------------------------------
  motw_xlsm:
    CommandLine|contains:
      - '.xlsm'
      - 'Zone.Identifier'
  no_motw:
    condition: not motw_xlsm

  # ------------------------------------------------------------
  # 4. Detection changement de permissions memoire via kernel events
  # Sysmon EventID 10 = ProcessAccess
  #   → Flags comme "MEMORY_PROTECTION" indiquent VirtualProtect/NTProtectVM
  #
  # OU ETW provider:
  #   Microsoft-Windows-Kernel-Memory / Event ID 5 (Page protection changed)
  # ------------------------------------------------------------
  mem_protection_change:
    EventID:
      - 10
      - 5
    SourceImage:
      - 'C:\Program Files\Microsoft Office
oot\Office16\EXCEL.EXE'
      - 'C:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft Office
oot\Office16\EXCEL.EXE'
    # Flag Sysmon indiquant changement de protection memoire
    AccessMask|contains:
      - 'VM_WRITE'
      - 'VM_EXECUTE'
      - 'READ_WRITE_EXECUTE'
      - 'EXECUTE_READWRITE'

  no_mem_change:
    condition: not mem_protection_change

  # ------------------------------------------------------------
  # 5. Aucun processus non-Microsoft ne doit modifier EXCEL.EXE
  # Utilise Sysmon EventID 11 (FileCreate) / Event 15 (FileStreamWrite)
  # ------------------------------------------------------------
  excel_write:
    EventID:
      - 11
      - 15
    TargetFilename:
      - 'C:\Program Files\Microsoft Office
oot\Office16\EXCEL.EXE'
      - 'C:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft Office
oot\Office16\EXCEL.EXE'
    Signed: "false"          # processus non signe
  unauthorized_mod:
    condition: excel_write

  # ------------------------------------------------------------
  # 6. Condition finale
  # ------------------------------------------------------------
  condition: excel_proc and no_xll and no_motw and no_mem_change and unauthorized_mod
